title: Beauford Delaney’s Self-Portrait
copy: The writer Henry Miller used the words above to describe his dear friend, the forever poverty-stricken artist Beauford Delaney. And looking at how Delaney described himself in this self-portrait, it’s easy to see why; the colors are rich and lively, almost joyous. Yet these vibrant tones seem to clash with Delaney’s distressed, uneven expression. One eye is completely white as if stricken by cataracts, while the other piercing black pupil stares out at the viewer disturbingly. Though beloved and admired by a host of artist friends including Miller, Georgia O’Keeffe, and Willem de Kooning, Delaney suffered from delusions and spent his final four years in St. Anne’s House for the Insane in Paris. He claimed his portraits—“defenses against the inner demons”—allowed him to temporarily stave off his illness. Take a closer look at Delaney’s Self-Portrait .
